Award.AwardTitle: A Data-Driven and Real-time Approach to Personalized Bundle Recommendation and Pricing; from Theory to Practice

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
A good pricing strategy plays a crucial role in any retailer's business process. This is largely due to the fact that pricing approaches are highly visible to both customers and competitors, and thus have an immediate and dramatic impact on the bottom line. The online market for retail goods has grown enormously over the past decade. The development of a sophisticated personalized product and price recommendation system can provide the necessary competitive edge for any Internet retailer, making the difference on the order of billions in profits. The challenge of the new retailing paradigm is to design models for bundling and personalized pricing that are able to extract value from the new streams of customer data that an e-tailer has access to. The goal of this research will be the development of a personalized bundling and pricing model that recommends a bundle of related products to a consumer, but at an incentivized price (lower than the sum of the prices of the individual items) during their online session.

The innovation in this model will consist of balancing several key factors in terms of bundle and pricing offerings simultaneously, while developing a new approach to personalized demand estimation. The focal points of the work consist of four considerations: (i) developing meaningful personalization models (in terms of bundling of products but also in terms of pricing these products), (ii) developing inventory balancing methods that will balance the tradeoff between losing money due to future markdowns and at the same time facing potentially future inventory stock-outs, (iii) developing interesting structural results and insights on how personalization can tradeoff with bundling in terms of the pricing strategies. Finally, and very importantly, (iv) developing efficient solution approaches (theoretically but also computationally, the latter using actual industry data) that could impact practice. The goal will be to combine these distinct goals in the modeling: personalization, inventory balancing, pricing insights and efficiency/practicality. This research will design innovative models, analyzing them first from a theoretical as well as an applied standpoint but also in exploring the relationships between them and testing them first with real data. Furthermore, this research will build an integrated framework, models and solution techniques from machine learning, integer optimization, stochastic and robust optimization to key personalized bundle pricing problems that are accessible to all, in order to help academics and practitioners in the area of pricing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The growing trend in online shopping in the recent years has given rise to a wealth of data that was not available before. This availability of data provides new opportunities to retailers including providing personalized services to individual customers.

Examples of personalized services include targeted personalized promotions and discounts as well as showing personalized assortments and bundle offerings.

In this project has been about coming up with data driven and practical approaching to personalized recommendations of bundled products and assortments but also offering personalized promotions and discounts to consumers.

We have developed and analyzed new models for this problem and tested our models with real data. That is, we have developed new models and algorithms that are theoretically interesting and sound but yet are practical and can eventually impact and improve practice.

A key aspect of this problem is determining the right underlying demand model. A challenge came when the products we considered were new. To accomplish this, we came up with a model for demand learning for new products that leveraged information from existing products. We came up with an algorithm that determined clusters of comparable products and assigned weights (probabilities) on how similar the new product is to each cluster of similar existing products.

An important and related problem we analyzed was which consumers to offer which discounted prices for these products. We devised a model that detects relationships and trends between different classes of customers even when one does not have access to social network data. Our model in this case allowed us to propose an algorithm that can target "influencial" customers and offer them the right products at the right prices.

This work allowed us to address important demand estimation issues as well as price optimization that have more general implications to the area of submodular optimization.

We tested our algorithms with data that we obtained from several collaborators. 

One of these was our collaborator from IBM research as well as Oracle. In particular, we obtained access to data sets from two large retailers and one from a premier airline. We demonstrated significant lifts in revenues on the order of 3-9% over current industry practices in all cases.

Our analysis presents counterintuitive insights from the data sets and finds that in the most inventory-constrained cases, our best algorithm performs within 15% of the optimal offline strategy, while in the best cases it obtains results within 3% of the optimal. It also shows how the algorithm smartly tradeoffs between personalization and. inventory balancing.

A key objective was also to disseminate our results to academics as well as practitioners. We accomplished this by submitting and publishing related papers and presenting the results of this research both to various universities, conferences, webinars for practitioners as well as to my classes at MIT.

Furthermore, several PhD students graduated with their thesis on this work.

Those include during the reporting period 2019-2020: Max Biggs (PhD summer 2019), Rim Hariss (PhD summer 2019), Tamar Cohen-Hillel (PhD summer 2020), Divya Singhvi (PhD summer 2020), Elaheh Fata (PhD summer 2020).

The papers that were accepted / published related to this work 

1)     A Data-Driven Approach to Personalized Bundle Pricing and Recommendation (with A. Papush and P. Harsha), MSOM, Published Online: July 2019.

2)     Detecting customer influence for targeted optimized promotions (with L. Baardman, S. Borjian, T. Cohen, K. Panchamgam), Accepted MSOM, July 2019. (2nd place in the Practice Based Research Competition of MSOM)

3)     Promotion Optimization in Retail (with M. Cohen), chapter in edited book Channel Strategies and Marketing Mix in a Connected World, editors Saibal Ray, Shuya Yin, January 2020.

4)     Data Analytics in Operations Management: A Review (with V. Misic), Appeared in MSOM, 2020.

5)     A Simple Rule for Pricing with Limited Knowledge of Demand (with C. Cohen and R. Pindyck), Management Science, Articles in Advance, June 2020

6)     An Efficient Algorithm for Dynamic Pricing Using a Graphical Representation, (with M. Cohen, S. Gupta, J. Kalas), POM, Appeared May 2020.

7)     Optimizing Promotions for Multiple Items in Supermarkets, (with M. Cohen, J. Kalas), Management Science, Published online June 2020.

Papers submitted and under review include

1)     Pricing for Heterogeneous Products: Analytics of Ticket Reselling, (with M. Alley, M. Biggs, R. Hariss, C. Hermann, M. Li), submitted to MSOM, (2nd round, Major Revision), (finalist MSOM Practiced Based Research Competition).

2)     Markdown Pricing with Quality Perception and Consumer Optimism: From Experiment to Theory, (with R. Hariss, W. Sinchaisri, Y. Zheng), (2nd round, Major Revision), MSOM.

3)    Distribution-Free Pricing (with M. Hu and H. Chen), submitted to M&SOM, (2nd round, Major Revision).

4)     Leveraging Newsvendor for Predictive Inventory Distribution at a Large Fashion e-Tailer, (with D. Singhvi and I. Spantidakis), submitted at MSOM, June 2020.

5)     Dynamic Pricing with Unknown Non-Parametric Demand and Limited Price Changes, (with D. Singhvi), submitted to Operations Research, June 2020.
